newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: U.S. vetoes candidacy of U.N. chief Boutros-Ghali.
newsitem.headline: U.S. vetoes candidacy of U.N. chief Boutros-Ghali.

text.p: The United States on Tuesday stood alone in vetoing a second term for Boutros Boutros-Ghali as U.N. secretary-general while all other 14 members of the Security Council voted in favour.

The vote, at the request of the United States, was by secret ballot on a resolution sponsored by 10 of the 15 Security Council members. It would have put the 74-year-old Egyptian in office for another five years, until 2001.
Washington's veto was expected to open the way for other candidates to enter the race for a five-year term as secretary-general beginning January 1, 1997.

The council has agreed to give priority to candidates from Africa on the grounds that if Boutros-Ghali is denied the second term given his predecessors, he should at least be followed by another African.
But the vote also indicated how little support the United States had mustered since June, when it announced it would veto Boutros-Ghali, saying he was not strong enough on reforming the world body.
U.S. officials also argue that the Republican-dominated U.S. Congress will not provide the money needed to pay off $1.4 billion in U.S. dues to the United Nations unless Boutros-Ghali is replaced.
Many members, however, believe that Boutros-Ghali has been made a scapegoat for failures in U.S. foreign policy and Republican opposition to the world body.
The United States, Britain, France, Russia and China all have veto power on the council.
The purpose of the resolution was to put on record the council's overwhelming support for Boutros-Ghali and isolate the United States.

Washington has been criticised for using the New York Times to announce its opposition to Boutros-Ghali and for precipitating a financial crisis by refusing to pay the $1.4 billion it owes the United Nations.
If the council were unable to choose an African, the contest would eventually be thrown open to candidates from other parts of the world.
